EU

Sources suggested that the ECB is unlikely to drop pledge next week to keep buying bonds until inflation heads towards target. The sources also suggest that the ECB's policy-making governing council stated any fundamental change to guidance was likely to come only later, with the March meeting, when policymakers get updated economic forecasts, seen as a more likely option. (Newswires)

ECB’s Villeroy said that the recent euro increase is a source of uncertainty that requires monitoring because of its possible downward effects on imported prices. He also highlighted that the Eurozone has not yet reached its inflation target and not in a self-sustaining way, while opining that the Eurozone still needs accommodative monetary policy, but can gradually reduce the intensity of monetary policy support. Villeroy was also confident that the ECB can manage a smooth exit from ultra-loose monetary policy. (Newswires)

ECB's Weidmann said that ending asset purchases in 2018 would be appropriate. Weidmann again warned about undesired consequences of the ECB's easing programme. Weidmann also said that analyst’s expectation for a mid-2019 rate hike is roughly in line with ECB guidance. (FAZ)

Berlin's SPD rejects coalition talks with Merkel's bloc, according to reports in Spiegel. (Newswires)

German CPI Final YY (Dec) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%) (Newswires)

 

SNB President Jordan reiterated that the CHF is still highly valued, he gave no expectations when Swiss interest rates will normalise. (Newswires)

 

FX

The greenback failed to hold on to early modest gains which saw the DXY edge back towards session lows. Elsewhere, EUR initially took a hit as the latest dovish ECB sources piece and comments from ECB’s Villeroy pointed to worry over the recent bout of EUR strength. EURUSD briefly printed below 1.22, before recovering to circa 1.2280. This came after ECB member Jens Weidmann noted that he is of the belief that the central bank should end its asset purchase programme in 2018 would be appropriate. Weidmann again warned about undesired consequences of the ECB's easing programme, and he also said that analyst’s expectation for a mid-2019 rate hike is roughly in line with ECB guidance.

 

COMMODITIES

Russian energy minister Novak said that the oil market is not yet balanced and sticks to previous forecast for 2018 oil prices of USD 50-60/bbl. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

US equities initially returned from the long weekend to fresh record highs with the S&P 500 and DJIA surmounting 2800 and 26000 levels for the first time ever. Despite the historical feat and some decent pre-market earnings, stocks then failed to hold on to gains and closed negative amid some government shutdown concerns and touted profit taking in an overbought market, while lower crude prices also added to dampener. SPX -0.35% at 2776, DJI -0.02% at 25796, NDX -0.32% at 6737.

Top sectors: Healthcare +0.47%, Consumer Staples +0.39%, Utilities -0.26%
Bottom sectors: Energy -1.23%, Materials -1.16%, Industrials -0.92%


The US curve flattened as the 2-year space was subjected to selling pressure after the elongated US weekend, although the Treasury space operated in a narrow range today. US T-Note Futures settled 1+ ticks higher at 122-31+.

US MARKET WRAP: USD continues pullback, stocks pull back from highs
content:
EQUITIES: SPX -0.35% at 2776, DJI -0.02% at 25796, NDX -0.32% at 6737

Top sectors: Healthcare +0.47%, Consumer Staples +0.39%, Utilities -0.26%
Bottom sectors: Energy -1.23%, Materials -1.16%, Industrials -0.92%

US equities fell afoul of lower crude prices despite decent enough pre-market earnings, as we moved back from fresh intra-day highs for the three major US indices DJIA, before me moved lower as the Dow failed to consolidate above 26,000.

TREASURIES: US T-Note Futures settled 1+ ticks higher at 122-31+

The US curve flattened as the 2-year space was subjected to selling pressure after the elongated US weekend, although the Treasury space operated in a narrow range today.

FOREX: DXY -0.62% heading into APAC trade

The greenback managed to post modest gains before the DXY edged back towards session lows. In terms of US specifics, reports suggested that former Trump strategist Steve Bannon has reportedly been subpoenaed by special counsellor Mueller. With subsequent source reports suggesting that Bannon was told to not answer questions before House Intel Committee about the White House and transition period. Elsewhere a Republican lawmaker told reporters that the possibility of a US government shutdown is a real possibility.

The EUR took a hit as the latest dovish ECB sources piece and comments from the ECB’s Villeroy pointed to worry over the recent bout of EUR strength. EURUSD briefly printed below 1.22, before recovering to circa 1.2280. This came after ECB member Jens Weidmann noted that he is of the belief that the central bank should end its asset purchase programme in 2018 would be appropriate. Weidmann again warned about undesired consequences of the ECB's easing programme, and he also said that analyst’s expectation for a mid-2019 rate hike is roughly in line with ECB guidance. It would seem that the EUR benefitted from a fresh bough of dollar weakness, as opposed to Weidmann’s (typically) hawkish comments.

USDJPY topped out in front of 111.00 following some verbal intervention from Japanese ministers in Asian dealing. The pair turned against a weaker dollar and moved in sympathy with US stocks, and last trades around 1.1030.

AUDUSD ran out of steam around 0.7975 as copper prices and iron ore futures fell (with Barclays predicting an imminent drop in the latter), before the USD weakness left the pair virtually unchanged on the day. The NZD/USD also fell back from best levels, with the pair not receiving much support a rise in the latest GDT dairy auction prices, as results were in line with futures market pricing.

USDCAD was choppy, but rangebound in front of tomorrow’s BOC decision. The cross moved away from 1.2400 as sources reports suggested that US President Trump is not inclined to pull out of NAFTA, but they did note that his standing is subject to a daily change. The pair finished the day around 1.2425.

SNB President Jordan reiterated that the CHF is still highly valued, and gave no expectations when Swiss interest rates will normalise. His verbal intervention did little as the CHF moved to best levels vs. the USD as the greenback softened across the board.

COMMODITIES: WTI crude futures settled at USD 63.73/bbl, down USD 0.57, Brent crude futures settled at USD 69.15/bbl, down USD 1.11

Crude oil unwound the bulk of yesterday’s gains as various banks upgraded their price forecasts to lower levels than we are currently trading at. We also heard from the Russian energy minister Novak who remained cautious, stressing that the oil market is not yet balanced and stuck to Russia’s previous forecast for 2018 oil process of USD 50-60/bbl.

Gold benefitted from the softer greenback, hovering around USD 1,340/oz in spot trade.

FX Daily Wrap: Usd in better mood after Blue (MLK) Monday
content: The Dollar has consolidated recovery gains, albeit in large part due to a Eur retreat on the back of dovish/bearish ECB impulses via sources and official comments (former suggesting no fundamental changes in policy guidance this month and Villeroy expressing some concern about the strength of the single currency). Eur/Usd briefly traded sub-1.2200 vs almost 1.2300 yesterday, with a couple of German SPD regional votes against the coalition Government proposal also weighing, but the headline pair held above support in the 1.2188-70 area, while Eur/Jpy pulled back further from 136.00+levels after earlier selling. Eur/Gbp extended the downside from 0.8900 despite some softer than expected UK inflation data that weighed on Cable (down to sub-1.3750 from 1.3800+ peaks). Usd/Jpy returning towards 111.00 compared to lows just under 110.50 and within the realms of heavy option expiries that run off on Thursday (some 2.5 bn between 110.80-111.00). Offers reportedly waiting at 111.00, and stops on a break above 111.20. Aud/Usd losing a bit more ground from 0.7978-86 key and fib resistance to sub-0.7950 lows amidst declines in copper prices and iron ore futures (with Barclays predicting an imminent drop in the latter). Nzd/Usd also back-tracking from best levels (0.7300+ to circa 0.7260) and not getting much in the way of support from a rise in GDT auction prices (virtually in line with futures). Usd/Cad trading nearer the bottom of a tight 1.2400-50 range ahead of Wednesday’s BoC policy meet with options indicating the prospect of a marked reaction (more than a big figure), as consensus for a 25 bp hike comes with a few calls (8/36 in a Reuters poll) for a hawkish on hold outcome (due to ongoing NAFTA caution). However, Usd/Mxn continues to fall on hopes of a positive NAFTA resolution (around 18.7500 at one stage). DXY looking to build a base above 90.500.

content:
16th January 2018

EARNINGS

IHS Markit (INFO) – Q4 2017 (USD) Adj. EPS 0.52 vs Exp. 0.50, Revenue 945mln vs Exp. 912.62mln. (Newswires)

Comerica (CMA) – Q4 2017 (USD) Adj. EPS 1.28 vs Exp. 1.21, CET1 capital ratio of 11.55. (Newswires)

Citigroup (C) – Q4 2017 (USD) Adj. EPS 1.28, ex-tax reform and items EPS 1.20 vs Exp. 1.19, Revenue 17.3 vs Exp. 17.2bln. Quarterly Fixed Income markets revenues of USD 2.4bln in Q4 decreased 18%. Quarterly Equity markets rev of USD 530mln, down 23% (Newswires)

UnitedHealth Group Inc (UNH) – Q4 2017 (USD) EPS 2.59 vs Exp. 2.51, Revenue 52.1bln vs Exp. 51.5bln. (Newswires)

 

DJIA

Apple (AAPL) – A Chinese consumer group is looking for answers on the slowing of old iPhones. Separately, the tech giant and Tencent have reached a deal which allows WeChat users to send monetary gifts. (Newswires)

Boeing (BA) – Citi raises co. price target to (USD) 380 from 305. (Newswires)

General Electric (GE) – The co. forecasts USD 6.24bln charge in Q4 following update on insurance review. Further, it sees EPS to be at the low end of guidance and expects a USD 3.4bln impact from tax reform. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs Group Inc (GS) & Morgan Stanley Inc (MS) – Xiaomi has chosen the two banks as sponsors for its IPO proposal which could result in the smartphone co. to be valued at USD 100bln. (Newswires)

IBM (IBM) – The co. and Maersk said they will form a blockchain joint venture to focus on global trade. (Newswires)

JP Morgan (JPM) – The investment bank reports its December net credit losses of 2.43% VS prev. 2.36% M/M. (Newswires)

McDonald's Corp (MCD) – Following a request from its top customers, the restaurant chain is to introduce environmentally friendly packages and recycling options by 2025. (Newswires)

Merck (MRK) – The pharmaceutical giant says its Keytryuda’s overall survival rate and progression free survival has significantly improved in combination with Pemetrexed and platinum chemotherapy for patients with non-small cell lung cancer. Further, its Keynote-189 trial met its dual primary endpoints. (Newswires)

Nike (NIKE) – Of note for the co., Adidas (ADDYY) is looking to increase its US market share by 15%-20%. (Newswires)

Wal-Mart Stores Inc (WMT) – The retail co. is to restructure its stores’ management and is looking to remove 3,500 co-managers and add 1,700 assistant store managers on a lower-paid role. On another note, the co. is to eliminate 1,000 corporate jobs. (Bloomberg)

 

S&P 500

Alliance Data (ADS) – The co. reports December net charge offs at 5.9% vs 5.8% M/M. (Newswires)

AT&T Inc (T) – Due to national security concerns, US legislators are urging the co. to halt commercial ties with Huawei Technologies and prevent China Mobile to enter the US market. (Newswires)

Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAC) / UBS (UBS) – The banks were not named for senior advisory role in Saudi Aramco IPO because they are not offering loans to the oil producer. (Newswires)

Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc (CMG) – The restaurant chain has entered into retention agreement with CFO Jack Hartung and a number of employees to encourage the continued service of employees as the co. searches for a new CEO. (Newswires)

Citigroup (C) – The bank is to raise pay for women & minorities to bridge the pay gap in the US, UK and Germany. (Newswires)

Ford (F) / Tesla (TSLA) / General Motors (GM) – Ford plans to increase electric vehicles investment to USD 11bln by 2022 and are also eyeing ways to make savings across the whole business. Separately, the automaker announced the 2019 Ford Ranger which offers driver-assist technologies, both on and off road, with production beginning later this year. (Newswires) 

General Motors (GM) – The automaker forecasts initial FY18 EPS at the high end of its (USD) 6 – 6.50, vs. Exp. 5.79, Further it sees a non-cash write down of USD 7bln in Q4. Separately, the CEO, Mary Barra, believes in NAFTA survival and other executives are still backing plans to build trucks in Mexico. (Newswires) (Newswires)

Lowe’s (LOW) – The retail home improvement co.’s price target has been raised to (USD) 116 from USD 88. (Newswires)

Raytheon Co. (RTN) – The defence name is to be awarded a USD 641.8mln government contract to perform Ballistic Missile Defense System test related activities. (Newswires)

Time Warner (TWX) – HBO is trimming its development pipeline to focus on quality content to compete with rivals. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOG) – The tech giant is re launching its map service in China, and it says there are no changes. (Nikkei / 9to5Google)

Amazon (AMZN) – BMO Capital raised its co. price target to (USD) 1600 from 1200. Separately, White House Press Secretary, Sarah Sanders, complained to the co. on twitter after her 2-year old son was able to order a USD 80 toy using Amazon Echo. (Newswires)

Baidu (BIDU) – The co. debuts block chain as a service platform. (Cryptovest)

Facebook Inc (FB) & Twitter Inc (TWTR) -  The two tech Chief Operating Officers, Sheryl Sandberg and Jack Dorsey, will not pursue re-election to Walt Disney's (DIS) board as conflicts of interest are emerging with Disney. (Newswires)

JD.com Inc (JD) – The co. forecasts to raise USD 2bln and plans listing overseas. (Newswires)

Netflix (NFLX) – The co. is exploring a potential release on Nintendo Switch. (Polygon)

Nvidia (NVDA) – Uber and Volkswagen to employ the co.’s artificial intelligence technology for self-driving vehicles. (Newswires)

Qualcomm (QCOM) / NXP Semiconductor (NXPI) / Broadcom (AVGO) – Ramius is to reject Qualcomm's tender offer for NXP. Further, Qualcomm are urging stock holders to reject Broadcom’s (AVGO) undervalued takeover. Further, Qualcomm targets (USD) 6.75 - 7.50 in FY19 Non-GAAP EPS with "high confidence". Establishes new USD 1b cost reduction program and cites accretion from NXP deal or large share buyback as being equal.  (Newswires / David Faber)

TiVo Corp (TIVO) & Comcast Corp (CMCSA) – TiVo is suing Comcast again over alleged patent infringement. The broadcasting company denied the violation and defended itself by stating it has created its own products. (Newswires)

Viacom Inc (VIAB) – The co.’s Shari Redstone still wishes to acquire CBS (CBS) , but the two are not in active merger talks. (Newswires)

 

OTHER NEWS

Arthur J Gallagher (AJG) – The co. is to acquire The Daniels Group; financial terms not disclosed. (Newswires)

subject: Barclays on UK CPI
content:
The slight decline in headline inflation was led by a technical adjustment to some core services components. In particular, similar to last year, air fares rose sharply in December; however, because air fares accounted for a smaller proportion of the basket of goods and services in 2017, the impact of the rise in prices on the contribution of air fares to the headline rate was smaller in 2017 than in 2016. Meanwhile, recreational and culture prices also came in on the weak side, with prices falling between November and December 2017, having been unchanged in the same period a year ago. This fall follows three successive months of relatively large increases in prices when compared with previous years. As we have highlighted in the past, the largest effects came from prices for games and toys, which fell between November and December 2017 by more than they did a year ago, along with audio-visual products, for which prices fell between November and December 2017, having risen in the same period last year.

Despite inflation falling back to 3.0%, the BoE is still committed to initiating an exchange of letters with the Chancellor to explain why inflation in November printed more than 100bp above target. That letter will be sent together with the publication of the inflation report on 8 February.

subject: Barclays look for iron ore to fall, averaging $50 in Q218, but they then expect a recovery in H218, raising their full year average forecast to $60
BofA Merrill Lynch January Fund Manager Survey
content:
· Average cash balance falls from 4.7% in December to 4.4% this month, a five-year low

· Allocation to equities jumps to two year highs of net 55% overweight, while allocation to bonds falls to four year lows of net 67% underweight; investors are the most overweight equities relative to government bonds since August 2014

· The balance of investors indicating they are taking out protection against a near-term correction in the markets falls to net -50%, the lowest level since 2013

· Investors are split on expected timing of equity markets peaking; “2019 or beyond” was the most commonly cited response (30%)

· Net hedge fund equity market exposure climbs nine percentage points to net 49%, the highest level since 2006

· The net share of investors saying global corporate earnings will rise 10% or more over the next year comes in at net 15%, the highest level since 2011; furthermore, 57% of investors would like to see companies increase capital spending

· Short Volatility (28%) for the first time overtook Long FAANG+BAT (26%) and Long Bitcoin (24%) as the trade considered most crowded

· Inflation and/or crash in global bond markets (36%) tops the list of tail risks cited by investors; the top three are rounded out by a policy mistake by the Fed/ECB (19%) and market structure (11%)

· Net 11% of investors surveyed expect the U.S. yield curve to flatten in 2018, the highest level in over two years

· When asked about preferred regions, global investors say they would most like to overweight Eurozone, EM and Japan; the UK continues to be deeply out of consensus, falling once more to a new record low since 2001 

· Investors rotate into cyclical plays: tech (the largest monthly rise since July 2014), industrials, EM and equities; they moved out of defensive plays like telecom (second lowest level since 2005), bonds, utilities, and the UK.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: UK CPI slowed to 3.0%, EUR slips after German coalition talk set back with Berlin SPD Branch voting to reject talks
content:
• UK CPI slowed to 3.0%, marking the first fall in inflation since June
  • EUR slips after German coalition talk set back with Berlin SPD Branch voting to reject talks.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Fonterra GDT auction as well as earnings from Citi, KMI, and UnitedHealth.

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly positive as region digested corporate updates and picked up the pace from the holiday-quietened lead due to the US market closure for Martin Luther King Jr Day. Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) and ASX 200 (-0.5%) traded mixed as Japan coat-tailed on a rebound in USD/JPY, while sentiment in Australia was dampened by weakness across commodity names including Rio Tinto which was pressured despite a beat on Q4 iron ore shipments, as the Co. also maintained full year guidance against expectations for an upgrade. Elsewhere. Hang Seng (+1.1%) outperformed and is on course for a record close, while Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) was also in the green amid several positive profit alerts and after a firm liquidity operation by the PBoC, which resulted to a net daily injection of CNY 270bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with prices range-bound throughout the day amid a lack of catalysts and after mixed results from a 5yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 160bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 150bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 10bln via 63-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4372 (Prev. 6.4574)

The Bank of France has invested some of its FX reserves in Chinese yuan. (Les Echos)

Chinese President Xi said in a phone call with Donald Trump on that all sides should work to keep up the “hard won momentum” over the nuclear situation on the Korean peninsula and work to restart talks. (FT)

EU/UK/US

EU is said to toughen conditions for a post Brexit agreement, as draft documents showed revised directives for EU chief negotiator Barnier with stricter conditions for a transition deal. (FT)

BOE’s external member Tenreyro said that at December meeting, she saw 'ample time' before the BOE would need to raise rates and expects a couple more hikes over next three years if economy performs as expected. (Newswires)

UK PM May is planning a speech to outline Brexit policy next month, while reports also stated that the EU withdrawal bill is expected to move to the House of Lords this week and pass. (Newswires)

ECB's Lane said he sees an abrupt Brexit to be a genuine shock that would risk the stability of the European financial system. (FT)

Norwegian officials tell Brussels they may seek radical rethink of their terms if UK has access to single market for key sectors. (The Guardian)

ECB's Hansson said that QE could be ended in one step without any problems. He also suggested that QE could end after September if the economy & inflation develop as now expected. He also noted that the Euro’s appreciation not a threat to inflation up until now, its rise should not be overdramatized. He is also of the belief that there is a need to adjust ECB communication; and that the ECB should discuss 'intensively' how to change its language, and suggested that the ECB should adjust its policy guidance before summer. Hansson is also of the belief that the ECB should hike rates a "few times" before starting to reduce the size of its balance sheet. (Boersen-Zeitung)

ECB unlikely to drop pledge next week to keep buying bonds until inflation heads towards target; according to sources. (Newswires)

US GOP leaders are said to be considering a spending deal to February 16th as they reportedly do not believe there is enough time to complete a fiscal year deal by Friday. (Newswires)

China called on US to avoid having official contact with Taiwan which would harm US-China ties, after US House recently passed bill encouraging visits between US and Taiwan officials. (Newswires)


UK inflation slowed to 3.0% in December, the first time since June that inflation has fallen back, backing the theory from the Bank of England that inflation was going to peak at the back end of 2017.

Berlin's SPD rejects coalition talks with Merkel's bloc, according to reports in Spiegel. The Berlin branch accounts for 3.8% of the SPD delegates.


EQUITIES

Most of the major bourses traded in positive territory with the FTSE 100 benefitting from a decline in the GBP after the inflation data. Continental and Michelin topped their respective bourses after reports that the former has hired JPMorgan to look at a break up of the business. There was more to cheer for the UK high street as Greggs and JD Sports both reported strong sales over the Christmas period.

FX

There has been broad, albeit modest recovery gains for the USD which have helped the Index rebound above 90.500, but it seems to be a fragile move awaiting confirmation and the return of US traders following Monday’s MLK market holiday. In the meantime, some short covering/long liquidation or position paring and profit taking, with the EUR seeing a bit of negativity on reports the Berlin branch of the SPD vote against a grand coalition – EUR/USD now around 1.2250 vs 1.2217 low and near 1.2300 peak yesterday. 1.2302 remains the nearest upside chart objective (another December 2014 high) before strong tech resistance at 1.2350, while support comes in around 1.2188-70. Cable retreated after (and before) the UK inflation data although the moves were relatively as the headline was in line with forecasts.


FIXED INCOME

Following the UK inflation data, the 10 year gilt inched closer to 124.00 at 123.98 and Short Sterling futures climb another tick or so to stand 0.5-3 ticks above yesterday’s settlement levels. Bunds also revisiting their Eurex session peaks (160.70), but just shy on Monday’s intraday high despite upside hedging for latest sovereign and corp supply via swaps, while USTs have edged a few ticks higher with the curve still flatter ahead of the return of US participants after the long holiday weekend. Only Empire State manufacturing scheduled, but another White House funding bridge to be crossed this week after IP data on Wednesday.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures are trading mixed with a number of big banks commenting on prices this morning. Goldman Sachs said they see increasing upside risks to their calls for the two major benchmarks, although this isn’t too surprising considering both trade above Goldman’s average forecast this year. Morgan Stanley, Soc Gen and Bank of America have all lifted their forecasts. Precious metals have slipped back as the USD has regained some ground, with palladium pulling back from the record high hit on Monday. Base metals have seen similar price action with copper down just shy of 1% on the LME.

subject: Bunds: inching higher after modest opening mark up
content: A firmer start for the 10 year German benchmark, initially in line with an uptick in longer dated US Treasuries overnight (amidst mild curve flattening), and then on latest reports about Berlin’s SPD party rejecting a grand coalition (although this appears to be a re-run of news that broke late yesterday and the region forms only a very small proportion). Bunds have been up to 160.56, 22 ticks above Monday’s close and +14 ticks from the low so far, while the corresponding yield is around 0.58%, but on the new 2028 bond which has been trading several basis points over the old 2027 maturity since launch last week. Back to the core debt future, yesterday’s high (160.76) will form some kind of chart resistance ahead of 160.85-90, and then 161.00 as a psychological round number.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Continental (CON GY) has hired JPMorgan to advise on a possible break up, according to sources
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

16th January 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly positive as region digested corporate updates and picked up the pace from the holiday-quietened lead due to the US market closure for Martin Luther King Jr Day. Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) and ASX 200 (-0.5%) traded mixed as Japan coat-tailed on a rebound in USD/JPY, while sentiment in Australia was dampened by weakness across commodity names including Rio Tinto which was pressured despite a beat on Q4 iron ore shipments, as the Co. also maintained full year guidance against expectations for an upgrade. Elsewhere. Hang Seng (+1.1%) outperformed and is on course for a record close, while Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) was also in the green amid several positive profit alerts and after a firm liquidity operation by the PBoC, which resulted to a net daily injection of CNY 270bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with prices range-bound throughout the day amid a lack of catalysts and after mixed results from a 5yr JGB auction.

FTSE

GKN (GKN LN) – Activist hedge fund Elliott has disclosed a stake in the company, as well as a stake in potential GKN suitor Melrose (MRO LN). (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) – Co. Said it could ship up to an additional 10mln tonnes of iron ore this year after reporting a 1% rise in shipments in 2017. Co. has stuck to its target of 510K-610K tonnes of mined copper and 225K-265K tonnes of refined copper. Aluminium production is expected to reach 3.5mln-3.7mln tonnes. (Newswires)

Ryanair (RYA LN) – The co. says that it has contacted Austrian administrator of airline Niki to express its interest in buying it. (Newswires)

Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. has agreed to acquire a stake in solar company Silicon Ranch Corporation with the initial investment to reach up to USD 217mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ASSOCIATED BRITISH FOODS (ABF LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT BY BARCLAYS

RPC (RPC LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERG

INCHCAPE (INCH LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERG

DAX

Continental (CON GY) – Co. has hired JPMorgan to advise on a possible break up, according to sources. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Nine banks, including Deutsche Bank, have been accused of conspiring to rig a Canadian rate benchmark. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Covestro (1COV GY) – Co. expects a EUR 85mln positive one-off for 2017 from the new US tax regime. (Newswires)

Hugo Boss (BOSS GY) – Co. says Q4 currency Adj. group sales up 5%. Co. says 2017 goals have been achieved. Growth was mostly due to strong sales in own retail business. (Newswires)  

Uniper (UN01 GY) – Fortum’s bid for the company is scheduled to expire. (Newswires)

CAC

Engie (ENGI FP) – Co. hopes to boost earnings growth and partnerships in its core businesses of renewables, grids and energy services in 2017, after an estimated 5% gain in core earnings in 2017. (Newswires)

Peugeot (UG FP) – 2017 worldwide sales up 15.4% to 3.6mln vehicles. Co. said market share increased in all host countries in Europe apart from the UK. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

EuropaCorp (ECP FP)/Mediawan (MDW FP) – Mediawan is in talks to buy a majority stake in EuropaCorp. (Newswires)  

BROKER MOVES

SCOR (SCOR FP) UPGRADED TO SECTOR PERFORM FROM UNDERPERFORM BY RBC

PAN-EUROPE

ABN AMRO (ABN NA) – Q4 results are expected to include several large incidentals in operating income and operating expenses. (Newswires)  

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) – Co. CEO says automaker has not held any talks with Chinese automakers. Separately, co. says that US tax reform is worth around USD 1bln to the automaker in 2018. (Newswires)

Yoox Net a Porter (YNAP IM) – Co. said 2017 prelim net revenue was EUR 2.1bln, in line with expectations. 2017 prelim orders of 9.5mln (Prev. 8.4mln). (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

IBEDROLA (IBE SM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SOCGEN

UMICORE (UMI BB) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL BY CREDIT SUISSE

SMI

Flughafen Zurich (FHZN SW) – Co reported December passenger number were up 3.3% to 2.17mln. (Newswires)

Lindt & Spruengli (LISN SW) – Co. reported a 4.8% increase in 2017 annual sales, but North American market remained tough. (Newswires)

Novartis (NOVN VX) – Co.’s generics business Sandoz said its regulatory submission for proposed biosimilar adalimumab was accepted by the FDA. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ZURICH INSURANCE (ZURN SW) UPRGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM BY RBC

SCANDINAVIA

Marine Harvest (MHG NO) – Reports Q4 operational EBIT EUR 177mln against EUR 172mln. (Newswires)

US

US markets were closed on Monday for a public holiday.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equities mostly higher across the board with Hang Seng on course for a record close, while ASX 200 is weighed by Rio Tinto
content:
• Asian equities mostly higher across the board with Hang Seng on course for a record close, while ASX 200 is weighed by Rio Tinto.
  • JPY softens vs. counterparts despite Japanese Finance Minister Aso downplaying recent FX moves.
  • Looking ahead, UK Inflation, Fonterra GDT Auction and earnings from Citi, UnitedHealth and CSX.

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly positive as region digested corporate updates and picked up the pace from the holiday-quietened lead due to the US market closure for Martin Luther King Jr Day. Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) and ASX 200 (-0.5%) traded mixed as Japan coat-tailed on a rebound in USD/JPY, while sentiment in Australia was dampened by weakness across commodity names including Rio Tinto which was pressured despite a beat on Q4 iron ore shipments, as the Co. also maintained full year guidance against expectations for an upgrade. Elsewhere. Hang Seng (+1.1%) outperformed and is on course for a record close, while Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) was also in the green amid several positive profit alerts and after a firm liquidity operation by the PBoC, which resulted to a net daily injection of CNY 270bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with prices range-bound throughout the day amid a lack of catalysts and after mixed results from a 5yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 160bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 150bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 10bln via 63-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4372 (Prev. 6.4574)

The Bank of France has invested some of its FX reserves in Chinese yuan. (Les Echos)

Chinese President Xi said in a phone call with Donald Trump on that all sides should work to keep up the “hard won momentum” over the nuclear situation on the Korean peninsula and work to restart talks. (FT)

 


UK

EU is said to toughen conditions for a post Brexit agreement, as draft documents showed revised directives for EU chief negotiator Barnier with stricter conditions for a transition deal. (FT)

BOE’s external member Tenreyro said that at December meeting, she saw 'ample time' before the BOE would need to raise rates and expects a couple more hikes over next three years if economy performs as expected. (Newswires)

UK PM May is planning a speech to outline Brexit policy next month, while reports also stated that the EU withdrawal bill is expected to move to the House of Lords this week and pass. (Newswires)

ECB's Lane said he sees an abrupt Brexit to be a genuine shock that would risk the stability of the European financial system. (FT)

Norwegian officials tell Brussels they may seek radical rethink of their terms if UK has access to single market for key sectors. (The Guardian)
 

EU

ECB's Hansson said that QE could be ended in one step without any problems. He also suggested that QE could end after September if the economy & inflation develop as now expected. He also noted that the Euro’s appreciation not a threat to inflation up until now, its rise should not be overdramatized. He is also of the belief that there is a need to adjust ECB communication; and that the ECB should discuss 'intensively' how to change its language, and suggested that the ECB should adjust its policy guidance before summer. Hansson is also of the belief that the ECB should hike rates a "few times" before starting to reduce the size of its balance sheet. (Boersen-Zeitung)

Greece parliament approved austerity measures ahead of Jan 22nd Eurozone finance ministers meeting where they will review unlocking EUR 6.5bln in bail out funds for Greece. (Newswires)

German SPD party leader Schulz is `optimistic' that the majority will vote for talks with Merkel. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, USD/JPY found some reprieve from the recent selling and rose to within close distance of the 111.00 level, while JPY-crosses were also underpinned in tandem despite comments from Japanese Finance Minister Aso who downplayed the importance of the recent FX market situation and said he doesn’t see a big deal with USD/JPY at around 110.80. Elsewhere, the rest of major currencies were quiet and held on to the prior day’s gains against the greenback, with EUR/USD firmly above 1.2200 after the recent hawkish tone from ECB’s Hansson who said QE could be ended in one step without any problems, and with AUD/USD kept afloat after the PBoC set the firmest reference rate since December 2015.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with a mild-pullback observed in oil, which saw Brent crude prices struggle to remain above USD 70/bbl. Fundamental news remained thin from yesterday’s US holiday closure which also delays this week’s API release to Wednesday, while reports also noted that Chinese crude oil futures trading is likely to be delayed till March instead of some prior expectations of a start this Thursday. Elsewhere, copper was indecisive and gold prices were also range-bound alongside a somewhat choppy greenback.

China crude oil futures trading will not begin this Thursday as some expected and instead could begin in March, according to press reports. (Newswires)

US

US GOP leaders are said to be considering a spending deal to February 16th as they reportedly do not believe there is enough time to complete a fiscal year deal by Friday. (Newswires)

China called on US to avoid having official contact with Taiwan which would harm US-China ties, after US House recently passed bill encouraging visits between US and Taiwan officials. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly higher with Nikkei 225 coat-tailing on USD/JPY reprieve and Hang Seng reattempts claim on record closing high
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly positive as region digests corporate updates and picks up from the holiday-quietened lead due to the US market closure for Martin Luther King Jr Day. Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) and ASX 200 (-0.2%) are mixed with Japan coat-tailing on a rebound in USD/JPY, while sentiment in Australia is dampened by weakness across commodity names including Rio Tinto which was pressured despite a beat on Q4 iron ore shipments, as the Co. also maintained full year guidance against expectations for an upgrade. Elsewhere. Hang Seng (+0.8%) looks to reattempt a claim on the all-time closing high level and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) is also in the green amid several positive profit alerts and after a firm liquidity operation by the PBoC, which resulted to a net daily injection of CNY 270bln.

In FX markets, USD/JPY found some reprieve from the recent selling and approaches the 111.00 level, while JPY-crosses were also underpinned in tandem, with GBP/JPY and EUR/JPY reclaiming the 153.00 and 136.00 handles respectively. This was despite comments from Japanese Finance Minister Aso who downplayed the importance of recent FX market conditions and said he doesn’t see a big deal with USD/JPY at around 110.80. Elsewhere, the rest of major currencies are quiet and hold on to the prior day’s gains against the greenback, with EUR/USD mildly extending on from the recent hawkish tone from ECB’s Hansson who said QE could be ended in one step without any problems, and with AUD/USD supported after the PBoC set the firmest reference rate since December 2015.

Finally, price action in 10yr JGBs is flat amid a lack of catalysts and as participants are also side-lined ahead of a 5yr auction later.
